channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Lebanese Army Deploys Troops to War-Torn Areas as Cease-Fire Appears to Hold
item.description: Israel’s military said it had fired on people arriving in parts of southern Lebanon because they were violating a cease-fire agreement with the militant group Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack

item.title: With Trump Returning and Hezbollah Weakened, Iran Strikes a Conciliatory Tone
item.description: As Iran faces domestic and foreign challenges, its bellicose rhetoric on the United States and Israel has given way to signs that it wants less confrontation.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Tehran showing Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and his predecessor, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

item.title: Indian Thieves See a Gold Mine in Exams for Government Jobs
item.description: In a country where government jobs are highly coveted, the tests that govern hiring are a lucrative target for criminal gangs.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Atul Loke
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times

item.title: 850-Year-Old Smithfield Meat Market in London to Close
item.description: The historic site in Britain’s capital has been a market for centuries. The local authority voted this week to close it.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Smithfield has been the site of a market since at least 1174. The current market was built in 1860s.

item.title: Chinese Women Mobilize Against Subpar Sanitary Pads
item.description: An online campaign has prompted major pad manufacturers to apologize. Regulators said they would consider women’s criticisms when writing new standards.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Wendy Wu/South China Morning Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A shelf of feminine hygiene products in a Beijing 7-Eleven convenience store.

item.title: Australia Bans Social Media for Everyone Under 16
item.description: The law sets a minimum age for users of platforms like TikTok, Instagram and X. How the restriction will be enforced online remains an open question.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: In Melbourne on Wednesday. Australia passed a social media ban for children despite feasibility concerns.

item.title: E.U. Vessels Surround Anchored Chinese Ship After Cables Are Severed in Baltic Sea
item.description: Multiple countries are investigating and the authorities in Europe say they have not ruled out sabotage. But U.S. intelligence officials have assessed that the cables were not cut deliberately.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Muyi Xiao and Riley Mellen
item.media:credit: Mikkel Berg Pedersen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A bulk carrier called the Yi Peng 3 traveling under a Chinese flag was being monitored by Danish naval patrol vessels.

item.title: India’s Exam Leaks Underline the Nation’s Bigger Problem
item.description: The economy has failed to create enough good jobs, so a government post appeals to far more people than there are openings, fueling desperation.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Indian police officers checking the documents of people preparing to take exams to join the police force outside the examination center in Meerut, Uttar Pradesh, in August.

item.title: Russia Launches Huge Bombardment of Ukraine and Signals More to Come
item.description: Ukraine said the attacks targeted energy infrastructure. President Vladimir V. Putin said they were retaliation for Kyiv’s use of long-range American missiles.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Taking shelter in a subway station after an air raid warning in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Thursday.

item.title: A Top Chinese Commander Is Suspended Under Suspicion of Corruption
item.description: The case of Adm. Miao Hua suggests the persistence of graft at high levels of the military, despite the efforts by Xi Jinping to stamp out corruption.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Adm. Miao Hua arriving at the Pyongyang Airport in Pyongyang, North Korea, in 2019. Until recently, he was in charge of a group that helps enforce Communist Party discipline in the military.

item.title: President João Lourenco of Angola Discusses Biden’s Upcoming Visit
item.description: President João Lourenço of Angola has worked hard to strengthen his country’s partnership with the United States and says the recent election won’t derail that.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Joao Lourenco, the president of Angola, at the presidential palace in Luanda, Angola.

item.title: What to Know About Australia’s Social Media Ban for Children Under 16
item.description: Critics say big questions remain not only about how the new law will be enforced, but also about whether the ban will really protect young people.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The Australian government has called the legislation a “world leading” move to protect young people online.

item.title: Will Lebanon Deal Break Gaza Deadlock? Experts Doubt It
item.description: Hamas is unlikely to compromise in Gaza, despite the decision by its ally, Hezbollah, to stop fighting. A deal in Gaza would also be harder for Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Israelis protested in Tel Aviv on Saturday against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government and called for the release of hostages held in Gaza.

item.title: The 50 Others Accused in France’s Pelicot Rape Trial
item.description: Dominique Pelicot invited men to rape his wife, whom he had drugged. The French media call them “Mr. Every Man” because they come from such ordinary backgrounds.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Co-defendants going through security at the court in Avignon, France, last week.

item.title: Hamas Faces a Future Without Its Most Important Ally
item.description: Israel’s offensive against Hezbollah and the cease-fire to stop the fighting in Lebanon have left Hamas increasingly isolated.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: A mosque in Gaza damaged by an Israeli airstrike. The Biden administration has tried to increase pressure on Hamas to make a deal with Israel and release the hostages it holds in Gaza.

item.title: The U.S. Is Building an Early Warning System to Detect Geoengineering
item.description: Balloon launches from around the world are part of a new kind of global alarm system: One that can detect if another country tries to dim the sun.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Tatsiana Chypsanava for The New York Times

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: The first day of a truce between Hezbollah and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Cars moving south on a busy road near Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. There are hopes that a cease-fire agreement will end 13 months of bloodshed.

item.title: As Plastic Talks Continue, a Reminder of What We’re All Exposed To
item.description: As international talks continue this week, a dozen U.N. officials reveal scientists tracked their exposure to many chemicals found in plastics.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Scientists can use silicone wrist bands to measure a person’s exposure to chemicals.

item.title: Syrian Rebel Groups Launch Largest Offensive in Years
item.description: Scores of people were killed after forces opposed to the government of President Bashar al-Assad overtook a Syrian military base, a monitoring group reported.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Clashes between fighters from Hayat Tahrir al-Sham and the Syrian Army in Aleppo on Wednesday.

item.title: How Have Israel and Lebanon Responded to the Cease-Fire?
item.description: The truce began Wednesday, bringing a fragile peace to Israel and Lebanon. Israeli troops are to withdraw in phases from southern Lebanon, and Lebanese military convoys headed south to protect the peace.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: A street in Tyre, Lebanon, on Wednesday, hours into the start of the cease-fire.

item.title: As Israel-Hezbollah Cease-Fire Takes Hold, Thousands in Lebanon Head Home
item.description: The cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah began on Wednesday, but much hardship and uncertainty lie ahead after a yearlong war that killed thousands and left widespread destruction in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Ben Hubbard, Aaron Boxerman and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: People celebrating as they drove south of Beirut, Lebanon, on Wednesday.

item.title: Northern Israel Somber as a Few Soldiers and Residents Trickle Through
item.description: While there were limited signs of life in the area, most residents were hesitant to head back without greater certainty that the cease-fire with Hezbollah would hold.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some Israeli troops have begun to return to Israel from Lebanon, but many remain.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: A Fragile Cease-fire in Lebanon
item.description: Plus, a post-election Thanksgiving.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of the Dahiya, south of Beirut, celebrated the cease-fire announcement yesterday.

item.title: Who Is Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing of Myanmar?
item.description: The country’s military leader has been accused of crimes against humanity over the army’s persecution of the Rohingya ethnic group.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, chief of Myanmar’s military junta, at a meeting in Moscow in 2022.

item.title: Pakistan’s Capital Is Turned Upside Down by Unending Protests
item.description: Residents of Islamabad are tiring of regular demonstrations demanding the release of the former prime minister Imran Khan, with the marches leading to clashes with security forces.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Supporters of Imran Khan marching toward Islamabad on Monday after clearing shipping containers placed by the authorities to block them.

item.title: Moscow Expels 2 German Journalists Over Allegations of Closing Russian TV Bureau
item.description: The German government denied it had taken action against Russia’s Channel One office in Berlin but said two Russian journalists no longer had residency permits.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The logo of ARD, the German public broadcaster, on the facade of its studio in Berlin.

item.title: French Intellectuals Decry Dissident Writer Boualem Sansal’s Arrest in Algeria
item.description: An outspoken French-Algerian novelist returned to his homeland and was promptly taken into custody at age 75.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Boualem Sansal in Paris in 2015. The Algerian-born writer became a French citizen this year.

item.title: Israeli Forces Keep Striking in Gaza Alongside Cease-Fire in Lebanon
item.description: While Israel and Hezbollah were finalizing a cease-fire to halt the fighting in Lebanon, Israeli strikes killed 33 people in Gaza, according to local health authorities.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: A damaged site in Nuseirat, in central Gaza, on Wednesday after an Israeli strike.

item.title: A Battered and Diminished Hezbollah Accepts a Cease-Fire
item.description: Thirteen months of war left Hezbollah weakened, isolated and desperate for a way to stop the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of the Dahiya, south of Beirut, celebrated the announcement of a U.S.-backed cease-fire on Wednesday.

item.title: France Suggests It Would Not Immediately Arrest Netanyahu Despite I.C.C. Warrant
item.description: The Foreign Ministry did not say outright that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel would be free to travel to France, but it argued that an I.C.C. rule on immunity may apply to him.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Marlise Simons
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, with President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris in 2023.

item.title: Oxford University Names William Hague Its New Chancellor
item.description: Mr. Hague, a former leader of Britain’s Conservative Party, was chosen in a vote by his fellow alumni to lead the elite university.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: William Hague at the Wimbledon tennis championships in England in July.

item.title: 3 Americans Are Said to Be Freed From China in Prisoner Swap
item.description: The Americans released, among others, a Chinese intelligence officer who was serving a 20-year sentence in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Mara Hvistendahl, Edward Wong and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The prisoner swap negotiated by the Biden administration has been in the works for months, officials said.

item.title: The Israel-Hezbollah Cease-Fire: What to Know
item.description: Under the agreement, Israel will gradually withdraw its forces from Lebanon over the next 60 days, and Hezbollah will not entrench itself near the Israeli border.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

item.title: Mystery Drones Spotted Over U.S. Air Bases in Britain
item.description: Small, unmanned craft were seen flying over four bases in England, the U.S. Air Force in Europe said. The Pentagon said that there had not been “any significant mission impact.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An American jet at R.A.F. Lakenheath, an air base in Suffolk, England, in 2020. Lakenheath was among the bases that drones have been detected flying over recently.

item.title: Cease-Fire Deal Leaves Beleaguered Palestinians in Gaza Feeling Forgotten
item.description: With a truce between Israel and Hezbollah taking hold, Gazans are losing hope that Israel’s war in the enclave will end anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Iyad Abuheweila and Ameera Harouda
item.media:description: A displaced Palestinian man gets a fire going next to a tent in Deir al Balah, central Gaza, on Monday.

item.title: I.C.C. Prosecutor Seeks Arrest Warrant for Myanmar Junta Leader
item.description: The International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor accused Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing of crimes against humanity toward the country’s Muslim Rohingya.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing attending a military parade in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, in 2021.

item.title: With Joy and Tears, Lebanese Return Home: ‘Look at All the Destruction’
item.description: A cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah allowed those displaced by the war to return to their homes. Many found buildings cleaved in half, crushed cars and ruined towns.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: People drive south from Beirut on Wednesday.

item.title: Will the Hezbollah Cease-Fire Draw Back Northern Israel Residents Displaced by War?
item.description: Some of the tens of thousands of Israelis displaced by the war with Hezbollah worried whether it was safe to go home.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Gabby Sobelman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Orly Gavishi-Sotto has been living in a rented house since leaving her hometown, Hanita, which is in northern Israel near the border with Lebanon.

item.title: Two Presidents, Two Policies, One Superpower: America in Transition
item.description: Even as President Biden brokers a cease-fire in Lebanon, President-elect Donald J. Trump is running his own foreign policy without waiting to be sworn in.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: Without waiting to move into the White House, President-elect Donald J. Trump effectively declared a trade war this week.

item.title: What Is Russia’s Oreshnik Ballistic Missile?
item.description: The weapon used for the first time against Ukraine last week is capable of carrying nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: A Ukrainian investigator with parts of a ballistic missile that Russia used in a strike on Dnipro.

item.title: Inside the Plastic Industry’s Battle to Win Over Hearts and Minds
item.description: Documents leaked from an industry group show how plastics companies are pushing back against a “tide of anti-plastic sentiment.”
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Aric Crabb/Digital First Media, via Getty Images

item.title: Record Snowfall Hurls Seoul Into Winter
item.description: The heaviest November snowstorm on record in the South Korean capital was a nuisance to commuters, and a delight to tourists, children and dogs.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

item.title: Protesters Supporting Pakistani Ex-Leader Are Dispersed in Crackdown
item.description: Thousands of demonstrators seeking the release of Imran Khan, the jailed ex-prime minister, fled the capital.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Police officers standing guard after conducting an overnight crackdown against protesters in Islamabad who demanded the release of jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The site of an Israeli airstrike in southern Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, on Tuesday.

item.title: Britain’s Emotional Debate Over Assisted Dying
item.description: As lawmakers prepare to vote on legalizing assisted suicide for the terminally ill in England and Wales, an intense public discussion has unfolded.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sarah Tarlow, whose husband Mark took his own life in 2016 after suffering a debilitating neurological illness. “I think it is cruel to make people die horrible, prolonged deaths against their will and that’s what the present situation currently does,” she said.

item.title: Namibia Election: What to Know
item.description: Voters head to the polls on Wednesday in the latest test for one of southern Africa’s liberation parties, which have been rebuked at the ballot box this year.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Timo Shihepo
item.media:description: Election posters in Windhoek, Namibia, days before the polls opened on Wednesday.

item.title: Meet One of Hong Kong’s Last Few Pro-Democracy Activists
item.description: For Chan Po-ying, a labor rights leader, life is one of constant police surveillance, even on hikes. But she finds solace from tiny gestures of support.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chan Po-ying posed for photographs in Hong Kong on Friday.

item.title: Trump’s Tariff Threat Pits Canada Against Mexico
item.description: The president-elect’s opening salvo in trade and border talks with the United States’ neighbors is casting a harsh light on the North American alliance.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Simon Romero
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada during a Group of 7 summit in Quebec in 2018.

item.title: Israel Approves Cease-Fire With Hezbollah to Halt War in Lebanon
item.description: President Biden said the 60-day truce, which the United States helped broker, would take effect early Wednesday, and was intended to become permanent, ending Lebanon’s deadliest war in decades.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli airstrikes on Lebanon continued on Tuesday, ahead of the proposed cease-fire.

item.title: Biden Announces Cease-Fire Deal Between Israel and Lebanon
item.description: With a deal to end more than a year of fighting between Israel and Hezbollah, the president turns his attention back to stopping the war in Gaza before leaving office.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden said the agreement would allow hundreds of thousands of civilians in both Israel and Lebanon to return home, provide security guarantees for Israel and create the possibility of renewed sovereignty for Lebanon.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Israel Approves Hezbollah Cease-Fire Deal
item.description: Plus, Mexico reacts to Trump’s tariff threats.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Beirut, yesterday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia and Russia Block Mention of Fossil Fuel Exit in Climate Resolution
item.description: A handful of oil-producing nations ensured that a United Nations General Assembly resolution on climate change steered clear of a call to transition away from fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Sultan al-Jaber, the president of the COP28 summit in Dubai last year, center, with other officials. The Dubai summit yielded a resolution that for the first time called for decarbonizing the world’s energy system.

item.title: Tariff Threats Show Trump’s Commitment to Upending Global Trade
item.description: The president-elect’s threat to hit Canada, Mexico and China with new tariffs is already rocking business and diplomatic relationships and could topple the trade pacts he signed in his first term.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Trucks waiting to cross into the United States in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, on Tuesday. Many multinational producers have set up supply chains that snake between North American countries.

item.title: Blinken and U.S. Allies Struggle with Wars as Biden’s Presidency Wanes
item.description: Top diplomats from the Group of 7 nations tried to project unity on Ukraine while discussing differences over Israel and anticipating the return of Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Tuesday at the end of the Group of 7 Foreign Ministers meeting in Fiuggi, Italy.

item.title: Israeli Leaders Blamed by Independent Inquiry for Oct. 7 Failures
item.description: After the Israeli government delayed a formal investigation into the Hamas attacks, an alliance of survivors and victims’ families set up their own inquiry. Their scathing findings were released on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Johnatan Reiss
item.media:description: Marking the first anniversary of the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks at the site of the Nova Festival massacre.
